Requiring certificate pinning in the mobile application: Certificate pinning is a security technique used to prevent man-in-the-middle (MITM) or on-path attacks, which are often the focus in these types of scenarios. When certificate pinning is implemented, the mobile application only trusts specific, predefined certificates for HTTPS communication. This helps prevent an attacker from using a fraudulent or compromised certificate to intercept the communication between the mobile device and the server. It's an effective solution to defend against on-path attacks, such as those where attackers intercept traffic to manipulate or steal data.

questions.question_text: A company’s Chief Information Officer requires that all visitors who connect to the Wi-Fi on an unused network port must have a posture assessment performed on their devices before being allowed network access. The company also requires that all wireless traffic be scanned for any abnormal behavior and the security team be notified before any actions are performed. Which of the following services should be configured to accommodate these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A. NAC (Network Access Control) ✅
 • Performs posture assessments before allowing device access
 • Can enforce policies (e.g., quarantine, deny, limited access) based on device posture
 • Supports guest access workflows
 • Ideal for wired or wireless networks

 ✅ Meets requirement 1 (posture assessment)

⸻

E. NIPS (Network Intrusion Prevention System) ✅
 • Monitors network traffic for anomalous or malicious activity
 • Can be configured to alert before blocking or taking automated action
 • Especially useful for detecting threats on wireless networks

 ✅ Meets requirements 2 & 3 (abnormal behavior detection + alerting)

Selected Answer: AC
A. NAC (Network Access Control): NAC is designed to enforce security policies on devices before granting them network access. It can perform posture assessments, ensuring that devices meet specific security criteria (e.g., antivirus installed, OS up to date) before they are allowed onto the network. This aligns with the CIO’s requirement that visitors’ devices undergo a posture assessment before accessing the Wi-Fi.

C. WLC (Wireless LAN Controller): The WLC manages the wireless network and can be configured to enforce security policies, including scanning for abnormal behavior in wireless traffic. This is important because the security team needs to be notified if there is any unusual behavior on the network, as outlined in the scenario.

o MDM: Mobile Device Management (MDM) primarily focuses on managing and securing mobile devices. While it can control app installations and usage on these devices, it doesn't necessarily implement a deny-all, permit-by-exception policy for all systems, especially desktops or servers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Supply chain visibility

A third-party management program is designed to assess and manage the risks associated with external vendors, contractors, and partners. By building such a program, the organization aims to gain better visibility into the security posture, risks, and potential vulnerabilities within its supply chain. This helps to ensure that third parties are meeting the organization’s security standards, reducing the risk of external threats entering the organization through insecure or vulnerable third-party relationships.
